courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Language and Intercultural Communication
courses.description: This course aims to help students enhance their communication with people who have a different language and cultural background. Topics include the concept of culture; language and cultural socialization; cultural variations in verbal and nonverbal communication; language, identity and biases; cultural diversity in perception, values, and worldview; intercultural-intimate relationships; culture shock and intercultural adjustment/adaptation; intercultural conflict and mediation; and English in the global workplace. This course should be of interest to local and international students, and is especially appropriate for those who plan to travel, study, or work abroad.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction to course/ Defining communication and culture

2. The dimensions of intercultural communication

3. Cultural patterns and communication: beliefs, values, and worldview

4. Cultural, linguistic and ethnic identities, cultural biases and intercultural contact

5. Intercultural adjustment/ adaptation: culture shock and recovery

6. Verbal interaction communication across cultures

7. Cultural variations in persuasion/ the structure of conversations

8. Nonverbal communication across cultures (body language, time and space)

9. Constructive intercultural conflict management

10. Intercultural competence in interpersonal relationships

11. The development of intercultural communication competence & intercultural personhood

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Pedagogical Grammar of English
courses.description: The aim of this course is to equip students with the grammatical knowledge that is essential for ESL teaching and learning. The first part of the course introduces students to key concepts involved in grammar pedagogy and teaching methodologies. The second part of the course covers grammatical forms and structures in English that may be particularly difficult for second language learners to acquire, with an emphasis on understanding the connection between form and meaning. Students apply what they have learned through conducting mini-lessons and team-teaching. At the end of the course, students should feel more confident about the use of grammar terminology in second language teaching and more knowledgeable about a task-based and discourse-oriented approach to grammar teaching in second language classrooms.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: ENGE1520 (only applicable to the 334 new curriculum)
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should:

‧ understand basic concepts in grammar pedagogy

‧ appreciate the relation between form, meaning and use in English grammar

‧ design grammar teaching materials that demonstrate understanding of grammar usage

‧ become more aware of the discourse functions of grammar forms in various text types

‧ become more aware of issues involved in the teaching and learning of English grammar
courses.course_syllabus: The aim of the course is to equip students with the grammatical knowledge that is essential for ESL teaching and learning. The first part of the course will introduce students to key concepts involved in grammar pedagogy and teaching methodologies. The second part of the course will cover grammatical forms and structures in English that may be particularly difficult for second language learners to acquire, with an emphasis on understanding the connection between form and meaning. Students will apply what they have learned through conducting mini-lessons and team-teaching. At the end of the course, students should become more knowledgeable about the contextual use of grammar and more articulate in the grammar terminology commonly used in teaching and learning.

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: English Semantics and Pragmatics
courses.description: This course focuses on how language is used to communicate meanings in context. The course covers the semantic principles of the meanings of words and sentences, integrated within the framework of the study of the communicative uses of language, as well as the pragmatic principles underlying linguistic communication. Among the major topics introduced are implicature, presupposition, speech acts, and politeness.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand the relationship between language and meaning at word, sentence and utterance level.

2. Understand different aspects of meaning in words, how they can be described, and how syntax contributes to meaning.

3. Understand pragmatic theories about how people use language within a context.

4. Apply knowledge of semantic and pragmatic theories to analyze real-life everyday communicatve situations.

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Lexical Studies in English
courses.description: This course introduces students to lexicology, the branch of linguistics concerned with the study of the vocabulary of a given language. Focusing on but not limited to English, this course aims at developing students’ sensitivity to the English lexicon and enabling them to apply linguistic principles in morphology, syntax, and semantics to the systematic description of English words. The course covers the notion of word meaning, the various lexical relations among words, the historical origin and development of the English vocabulary, the major word-formation processes in English, the nature and pervasiveness of figurative language, and ways English words are used in particular contexts.
courses.course_syllabus:

lexicology; history of English words

Part Two: Words in Linguistic Analysis

morphological, phonological and semantic analyses of words

Part Three: Words in Use

language variation; lexical change; collocations; MWUs

Part Four: Words in L2 Teaching and Learning

vocabulary acquisition; metaphor and metonymy in figurative language

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: English Literature and Culture Study Tour
courses.description: The students spend two weeks in the U.K. attending plays, visiting sites relevant to their study of English literature, as well as museums and art galleries. The aim is to enrich and broaden the students’ linguistic and cultural understanding. The impact of the study tour will be optimized by thorough preparation, a policy of English usage during the study tour and a series of writing tasks focused on the plays attended and cultural sites visited, including a reflective Tour Journal, all of which will be assessed on their return. Pre-departure discussions will prepare the students for every aspect of the tour.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students who take this course will be expected to:
- deepen their diverse interests in the arts and culture of Britain
- attain a richer understanding of the history of Britain
- improve their intercultural communication skills through immersion in an English-language environment

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: The World in English: an Oxford Summer Programme
courses.description: Students will be selected by a panel of senior staff based on achievement in relevant Department courses and willingness and likely capacity to benefit. Classes will be divided in two strands: "Literature, Linguistics and Society"; "Current Affairs: Britain and the World". Oxford tutors will conduct 4 hours' face-to-face teaching a day for 5 days a week. Students will spend some evenings and weekend days in excursions to London and Stratford for plays and other cultural sites. Fieldwork and cultural explorations will be closely supervised by College nominees and/or Department staff. Full reflective essays and diary-plus-video are required of all participants for presentation within CUHK at their own college presentation evenings, and to other English Department majors at university orientation events. Each student on return will be expected to volunteer for either a teaching role for underprivileged students or one of CUHK's ICARE service projects (Possibility of financial contribution being waived for needier candidates). Classes will take place in St Hilda's College Oxford for 3 weeks during the summer term, between second and third years.
courses.learning_outcomes:
- Enable students to develop a richer command of the world language
- Broaden students' understanding of global political and social issues
- On return and over their careers students will have a significant impact on the Hong Kong community
- Enhance CUHK and Hong Kong links with Oxford University
courses.course_syllabus:
- Classes in two strands: "Literature, Linguistics and Society", "Current Affairs: Britain and the World"

- Each student to read and report on their reading of a major daily national newspaper, along with a weekly publication such as the Economist, following a major theme or story of their choice, e.g. Euro/debt crisis, Middle East conflict, US elections, Africa development issues
- Assignments and diary with video component to be undertaken for assessment and presentations on return to a variety of groups; volunteering for the ICARE project or a teaching role for underprivileged students required

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Issues in Comparative Literature
courses.description: This course examines the field of comparative literature through a variety of readings in English and Chinese. It aims to introduce students to the main theories and methodologies of comparative literature and offers practical exercises in the application of these various approaches. After a preliminary discussion of the definition and scope of the field, other areas touched upon are: influence/reception studies; period/movement studies; genre/style studies; thematology/myth studies; interdisciplinary studies (e.g., literature and the other arts, literature and psychology, literature and linguistics, literature and literary theory).
courses.learning_outcomes: By the end of the course, students should be able to have acquired an acquaintance with the basic concepts and methodology of comparative literary study. They should be able to critique notions of modernization and modernity and problematize the terms East and West. They will have acquired knowledge of how certain fiction writers and poets in the twentieth century learned from cultures and literatures other than their own.
courses.course_syllabus:
Minor changes may be made if necessary.

Topic 1. Introduction

Topic 2. Period study—Modernisms: China and the West

Topic 3. Genre study—Poetics: China and the West—Image and Meter in Chinese poems and in Pound’s poetry.

Topic 4. Literature and ideas—Use of Confucian and Buddhist ideas in Pound’s poetry and other writers.

Topic 5. A two way influence study—China and Pound. (Wai-lim Yip, Yu Kwang-Chung)

Topic 6. The translation of poetry—translations of Chinese poetry by Pound and others including Arthur Waley, translations of Pound’s poetry into Chinese.

Topic 7. Thematology—the journey motif East and West, including references to the Odyssey and the troubadours.

Topic 8. Literature and other arts—Cubism and Vorticism (Picasso, Braque, Wyndham Lewis, Gaudier-Brzeska), montage in film (Eisenstein) and juxtaposition in poetry (Pound, Eliot).

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Communications for English Majors III
courses.description: The aim of the course is to strengthen students’ writing and speaking skills for a wide range of communicative contexts. Students will take advantage of different writing tasks to polish their descriptive, narrative and analytical writing skills. They will also learn to appreciate and apply different tones and styles for different workplace writing purposes. Through working on a feature report, students will also become more competent in research, analysis and the organization and presentation of ideas. In addition, students are encouraged to capitalize on the small-class environment by taking a proactive role in class discussions and presentations. The job interview and panel discussion exercises also provide students with opportunities to enhance their oral skills. It is hoped that by the end of the course, students can become competent and confident users of English across a variety of contexts.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisites: ENGE1310 and 1320.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to:
- Write more clearly, concisely and coherently, and speak with more confidence
- Adopt the appropriate diction, tone and style for different communicative contexts
- Produce professional workplace correspondences and perform in job interviews
- Conduct basic research on a chosen topic and develop intelligent ideas and opinions
- Express opinions and discuss ideas critically in a panel discussion setting
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Writing across different contexts
a) Through a series of very short writing exercises, you warm up your writing muscles and explore different types of writing. The aim is to help you understand the elements of good writing and also refine your choice of words and sentence structures.
b) discussing and writing about current affairs, you will learn to summarize, evaluate and persuade. Please take this opportunity to form the habit of reading international newspapers, magazines and journals.

2. Workplace English
First, get the job by preparing professional resumes and honing your job interview skills. Then do your job by writing proper business letters and workplace correspondences for different purposes.

3. Feature Report + Panel Discussion
What are some issues that you and your peers care about? (What makes you angry, frustrated, motivated, hopeful?) What are some phenomena that will shape your future? How can you find out more on these topics and, more important, form your opinion? You begin with a general topic and proceed to do research and analysis, and learn how to investigate and research issues intelligently, write a report that is informative and critical, and also prepare a panel discussion to orally present the gist of your work.

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Romanticism
courses.description: This course will address itself to the origin of Romanticism, its development and application as a conceptual model; it will involve the study of romantic poetry in the English tradition, with reference to some major themes such as nature, time, love and death.
courses.course_syllabus:
Romanticism

~ the complexity and multiplicity of the term “Romanticism”

~ Romanticism in English poetic tradition, its relation to Neo-classicism and Modernism

~ British Romanticism and European Romanticism

~ tensions in Romantic poetry:

- the role of imagination and of experience

- Romantic self and poetic persona

- self-expressiveness and sympathy

- radicalism and escapism

- the meaning of “nature”

- the supernatural, the exotic, and the gothic

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Modernism
courses.description: This course introduces students to Modernism as a literary and historical movement which attempted to redefine the major concepts of art, the role of artist and the value of aesthetics as offered and established by tradition. Emphasis will be put on the historical factors and implications of this significant cultural change from tradition to modernity. Works to be discussed may be drawn from poetry, drama, fiction, as well as other creative and critical forms of discourse.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, students should be able to:

1. understand and critique the modernist works chosen for study;
2. research on the intellectual background and political milieu of modernist writings; and

3. discuss important issues raised by the modernists that still bear relevance to our contemporary society.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction to the terms modernity and modernism.

2. A discussion of the impact of modernity as seen through literary representations of the city.

3. A discussion of the inter-relations between literature and life, and literature and politics as exemplified in

modernist works.

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: English Language and Literature
courses.description: This course is an introduction to literary stylistics, which, to put it at its simplest, is the application of linguistics to the study of literature. Its aim is to give some sense of the distinctiveness of literary uses of language in both poetry and prose. Non-literary as well as literary stylistics are studied so that an awareness of both the continuities and discontinuities between literary and nonliterary uses of language can be developed. The main theme of this course is that, while literature cannot be defined in terms of any distinctive language patterns, the study of language patterns that are central to or typical of it can give real insight into its nature.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To understand how readers construct the subjective experience of reading on the basis of the linguistic structures of a literary work.
2. To increase and deepen your experience of poetry, fiction and drama.
3. To help you understand both something of the distinctive qualities of literature, and of how literature relates
4. To other forms of discourse and it is not something sharply separated from them.
5. To help you understood the relations between poetry, prose and drama.
courses.course_syllabus:
The nature of literature, the language of literature, and the experience of reading literature.
1. The concept of style
2. Foregrounding
3. Rhythm and metre
4. Discourse architecture
5. Speech acts and implicatures
6. Point of view
7. Speech and thought presentation

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Major Concepts in American Literature
courses.description: From year to year the readings and the themes emphasized in this course will vary. Among the themes that enter more or less prominently into varying interpretations of American literature are egalitarianism, democracy, egotism, restlessness, regionalism, humour, lawlessness, hostility to traditional forms and ways of doing things, homoeroticism, and (especially in the twentieth century) the city, materialism, and the perils of the machine. Nineteenth-century writers who may be represented include Hawthorne, Poe, Emerson, Thoreau, Whitman, Melville, Dickinson, Twain and James. Twentieth-century writers who may be represented include Cather, Frost, Anderson, Stevens, William Carlos Williams, Pound, Ransom, Cummings, Fitzgerald, Faulkner, Hemingway, Tennessee Williams, Miller, Mailer, Updike, Robert Lowell and Sylvia Plath.

courses.subject: ENGE

courses.description: This course investigates the basic concepts and issues relevant to a critical understanding of the relationship between literature and culture in the context of socio-historical changes. Selected literary works will be read as the expression of cultural problems and cultural analysis attempted in the light of its broader implications for literary interpretation. While the specific topic may vary from year to year, some typical examples are: popular culture, postmodern culture, third-world culture, revolutionary culture, culture and resistance and comparative culture.

Subject specific skills.

On successful completion of this course you will have developed: analytical skills in relation to visual and written texts; organisational skills in the preparation of various writing and presentation assignments; basic research skills using textual and visual sources; basic writing skills in standard academic formats (presentations, essays).

Transferable skills.
On successful completion of this course you will have: become confident in expressing your views, asking questions, and responding to others; become more adept at giving formal presentations of your work.

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Literature and Religion
courses.description: This course will approach the relations between literature and religion with regard to both “form” and “content”. Its first part will concentrate on overall questions about the nature of language patterns and uses in both religious and literary contexts. There are a number of very striking similarities here, and we will ask what these say about the nature of both religion and literature. This course’s second and final parts will concentrate on insights about religious and literary forms of language and their uses to the study of particular literary, and to some extent religious, texts. The religious dimension of the course will relate mainly to Judaeo-Christian forms of religion, but attention will also be given to other, particularly of course Chinese, forms of religion.
courses.learning_outcomes:
It is hoped that after taking this course students will be able to:
- read literary texts more closely;
- have a better understanding of how important Christian mysteries and concepts are for Western writers
- have a better understanding of the literary concepts and motifs that are important for other religion traditions (Judaism, Hinduism, Buddhism, & Islam
- differentiate between different styles of writing in the Bible
- have a better understanding of how literature can embody religious and ethical worldviews
- have a better understanding of the main arguments against religion
courses.course_syllabus:

- How do Christian writers use religious mysteries and ideas in their writings?
- How do writers from other religious backgrounds (Judaism, Hinduism, Buddhism, & Islam) incorporate elements of their religious belief into their work?
Religious themes we will cover inlcude: The Garden of Eden, Faith and Belief, Apocalypse, Evil, The Afterlife, Sacrifice and religious mysteries such as Incarnation

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Literature and Education
courses.description: Education is one of the major ways in which a society imparts knowledge and skills on, and develops the characters and potentials of, its citizens, and the teacher is a key figure in this process. In this course, we will explore the topic of education and representations of the teacher in literature by focusing on fiction and drama from various historical and cultural contexts. The course will examine issues which are both socio-cultural and literary, and which will include: the impact of education and teachers on individual development and growth as represented in the texts; the ideological implications of education and teachers; and a comparison between the ways education is valued in the East and the West. It will also analyze the socio-historical contexts behind the works, in order to understand how these helped shape the portrayals of education and teachers in them. Some of the questions the course will tackle are: What does education have to do with literature? How does the representation of education and the teacher figure vary across writers, time, place and culture? What are some of the assumptions behind and implications of these different portrayals? And what relevance does thinking about education and the teacher in literature have on literature students?
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Analyze the literature studied, and explore the importance of the issue of education and the teacher figure in it.
2. Examine the relationships between literary representation of education and the teacher and socio-cultural conditions and assumptions.
3. Investigate the connections between the lives, literary methods and perspectives on education of the major authors studied.
4. Reflect on the role of literature in education, the meanings and values of education, and their own potential future roles as educators.
5. Develop further skills in critical and creative thinking, and oral and written communication.

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Writing a Life Between Languages
courses.description: This course aims first to introduce students to autobiography, one of the most popular forms of writing in the contemporary world. It will raise such questions as, why has this kind of narrative been so attractive to writers in cross-cultural situations, such as Chinese-Americans? The course will focus specifically on a group of (mainly American) immigrant autobiographers who write about the experience of living between a first language and English. They raise a range of fascinating questions about language and identity. Students will be asked to reflect on these questions and on the similarities and differences between these writers’ lives and their own experience in Hong Kong. The course will aim to teach students how to approach, analyse and theorize about autobiographical narratives. Students will be given opportunity to develop their analytical skills in essay-type responses to the prescribed texts. They will also be given opportunity to develop their narrative skills in their own life-writing, using the prescribed texts as models. Both forms of written exercise are designed to extend, as well as test, students’ understanding of autobiography as a genre.
courses.learning_outcomes:
• To teach students how to approach, analyze and theorize about autobiographical narratives.

• To develop analytical skills in essay-type responses to prescribed texts.

• To develop their narrative skills in their own life writing, using the prescribed texts as models.

• To develop and test student understanding of autobiography as genre.

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Reading and Writing Short Stories
courses.description: This course follows ENGE3260 but is not dependent on it. It provides an introduction to the craft of writing short stories. Students will read and analyse a range of short stories of diverse styles and forms from the beginnings of the genre to the present day. Particular attention will be given to contemporary stories written in Hong Kong. Students will be encouraged to use these texts as models for their own creative responses. The course aims both to deepen and broaden students’ understanding of the short story genre as well as to offer them the opportunity of gaining practical expertise in creative writing.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Students learn to recognize the part played by various features of a short story such as point of view, narration, shape, beginnings and ends, focus and narrative voice.

2. Students learn to recognize various styles of short story such as realist, modernist (mosaic style), metafictional.

3. Students come to understand how certain strategies tend to enhance the quality of a story, such as “showing” versus “telling”, or planting a seed of meaning at the beginning of a story.

4. Students learn to recognize the salient strengths and weaknesses in their work and those in the work of others.

5. They learn how to give constructive advice to their peers on how to improve their writing.

6. Students learn how to write a creative response to a story they have read by changing the point of view, for example, or imitating its style.

7. Students learn how to plan a complete original story, write it, respond to feedback and revise it.
courses.course_syllabus:

Students learn the importance of adopting a consistent point of view

Setting and dialogue

Students learn about “showing” versus “telling”

Students learn about having a clear focus

Students learn that these are important in shaping a story.

Characterization

Students learn how to build characters around focal ideas

Planning and plotting

Students learn about writing as an act of discovery

Revising

Students learn about the importance of drafting and redrafting

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Writing for the Stage
courses.description: This course is a play-writing seminar and workshop and aims to deepen students’ understanding of drama as well as giving them practical experience in creating original theatrical works. In a seminar setting, the class will read and analyse some works of modern English-language playwrights, as well as practise various styles and genres of drama during in-class writing exercises. The students will engage in intensive reading and critique of one another’s work and spend time writing and rewriting independent assignments such as dialogues, monologues, and scenes, culminating in the creation of a one-act play that will be performed in either a staged production or dramatic reading at the end of the term.
courses.learning_outcomes: The course will deepen students’ knowledge and critical understanding of dramatic literature and of the modern theatre; develop their creative and dramatic writing skills; increase their familiarity with various registers of contemporary and colloquial English speech; enhance their competence and confidence in written and oral self-expression in English. By the end of the course, all students will have a polished portfolio of their own dramatic writing, and will be in a position to stage their own original one-act plays.
courses.course_syllabus:
Students will read, discuss and perform plays and extracts from modern English-language theatre, with a view to understanding how the masters of the craft achieved their effects.

Students will gain a feel for the dynamic theatre by performing and improvising scenes, with discussion of the shape of drama, the need for visual effect, and the need to imagine how the playwright wants the play to be performed.

Students, in small groups, will produce one-act plays. They will perform them for the class, but will be assessed primarily on the writing.
courses.feedback_evaluation: In the course of the term, the teacher will closely monitor student performance of the regular writing and reading tasks to check whether the expected developmental outcomes are being realized. The teacher will also survey the students mid-course to evaluate student perception of teaching and learning in the course. Adjustments of approach and emphasis may be made in response to those forms of monitoring. There will then be the regular Faculty end-of-course evaluation questionnaire, in response to which the teacher will write a self-reflexive commentary on the teaching and learning in the course, which he/she will then discuss with the Department chair. These reflections, as well as external examiner comments (if any), will be fed back into course re-design for the next time it is put on.

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Writing for the Screen
courses.description: This course is a film-writing seminar and workshop, which gives students both theoretical understanding of how films (both feature and short) work and practical experience in creating original short screenplays, as well as a grounding for longer works. The class will read film screenplays, as well as analysis of film and the screenwriting process. Students will also watch and analyse short films, scenes from longer works, and entire feature films (which will be screened outside of class hours). They will practise various elements of the film-writing process and engage in intensive reading and critique of one another's work. Besides weekly short writing assignments, the students will work on two short film screenplays—one an adaptation of a literary work and the other a completely original piece. Each student will then produce, or participate in the production of, one of these film scripts as a short video.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should:

• Be able to appreciate dramatic writing and its structure and style

• Be aware of the different elements that go into dramatic writing

• Be able to discuss and analyze the effectiveness of dramatic writing

• Discover their own voice in dramatic writing through writing exercises

• Become competent in how give constructive comments during workshops

• Gain appreciation of the continual quest for newness and innovation in the creative writing process.

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Hong Kong Literature in English
courses.description: Students will study Hong Kong literature in English in its colonial and postcolonial contexts. Works from different genres will be discussed to explore the following issues: the representation of Hong Kong and its people, the question of identity, the agency of its people, the impact of modernity and postmodernity, and the ideas of home and exile. Students’ analytical and critical skills will be sharpened to enhance their understanding of literary works, their awareness of the dynamic interrelationships between literature and social-political forces, and their appreciation of the meeting points between Hong Kong literature in English and Hong Kong literature in Chinese.
courses.learning_outcomes: By the end of the course, students should be able to have acquired an acquaintance with the basic concepts and methodology of comparative literary study. They should be able to critique notions of modernization and modernity and problematize the terms East and West. They will have acquired knowledge of how certain fiction writers and poets in the twentieth century learned from cultures and literatures other than their own.

courses.description: The course introduces students to English literature written in the Victorian period. Students will read and analyze Victorian literature drawn from the beginning to the end of the period, and from a range of different genres. Among the themes which may be investigated are religion, identity, propriety, morality, social class, reform, and gender. The course will also explore the relationships between literary themes and methods across these decades, and changing historical contexts and social issues. Time permitting, comparisons may also be drawn between such literary works and their visual representations, whether in film or art.

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Literature and Politics
courses.description: This course will cover key texts that deal with the relationship between literature and political theory. The course examines how major writers have dealt with such topics as nationalism, self-determination, political independence, totalitarianism, terrorism and animal rights. The course will introduce students to the political and historical context of each piece of writing and then examine the text in light of the relevant political theory. It will examine how political ideologies such as Marxism, socialism and conservatism have been important as motivating factors both for artists and critics. The course will examine political writings from a range of genres and from a range of literary periods.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students will examine various descriptions of political life

Students will be given the time and space to evaluate various political theories.

Students will be given the time and space to enumerate, describe, list, clarify, and even do algorithms on (should they choose to do so) different political ideologies described in and through literature and literary criticism.

Students will be given the time and space to explain the motivations for various canonical responses to political events by canonical writers

Students will be given the time and space to compare and contrast various claims made on behalf of forms of political ideology in literature and in literary criticism

Students will evaluate how appropriate different literary genres are for mediating political ideas related to distinct political ideologies

Students will analyse/assess/critique/re-imagine various institutional approaches to the censorship of politically sensitive subjects in canonical literature

Students will not be given the ability to predict their own marks for this course

Students will be given the time and space to create/design/reflect on 5-page essays on the relationships between literature and politics.

An unanticipated or anticipated extension (depending on the perspective of the teacher and student) of this course will be the learned ability to hypothesize about the nature of the relationship between political theories and literature.

Contents/ fundamental concepts: Literature and Politics, Plato’s Republic, Fredric Jameson The Political Unconscious

Contents/ fundamental concepts: Shakespeare and the Just War

Contents/ fundamental concepts: The relationship between literature and Marxism. The Communist Manifesto. The work of Charles Dickens.

4. Literature and the ‘Fight for Freedom’: William Butler Yeats -“Easter 1916”, “September 1913”

Contents/ fundamental concepts: Literature and nationalism, literature and political self-determination, literature and the fight for political independence. The political work of W. B. Yeats

5. Literature and State Control: George Orwell’s Animal Farm and “Politics Vs Literature: An Examination of Gulliver’s Travels”

Contents/ fundamental concepts: Literature and State Control. The work of George Orwell.

6. Literature and Totalitarianism: Alexander Solzhenitsyn One Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich and “The Nobel Lecture in Literature 1970”

Contents/ fundamental concepts: Literature and Totalitarianism. Literary descriptions of political oppression in totaliltarian states. Censorship.

7. FILM: The Dictator: Extracts from Charlie Chaplin’s The Great Dictator and Sacha Baron Cohen’s The Dictator

Contents/ fundamental concepts: Film and the satirical treatment of the dictator in two different political eras.

Contents/ fundamental concepts: Literature and fascist ideology. The politically controversial work of Ezra Pound and Thomas Mann. Contemporary descriptions of fascism in media and print journalism

Contents/ fundamental concepts: The literary reaction to terrorism in various political contexts.

11. Literature, Censorship, and Civil Disobedience: Aung San Suu Kyi:Letters from Burma. “Death in Custody 1-3” and “Teachers”

courses.description: This course focuses on the art of writing about Hong Kong. courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: The Contemporary African Novel
courses.description: This course introduces students to a selection of new writing from the African continent. It does so in order to demonstrate the diversity of writing emerging from the multiple and diverse contexts present in the continent. Although primarily interested in writing in English, this course may also explore works in translation to bring into sharp relief the heterogeneous and variegated nature of the contemporary African novel. The focus on contemporary writing from the continent (read as works published within the last 10 years) means that writers other than those typically studied on such courses are to be read. The emphasis here is on the introduction of new writers to students, and the socio-historical contexts in which they write. To this end, students will enrich their understanding of world literature. Although not required, those who have taken ENGE3250 “Other Literature in English – An Introduction to African Literature” prior to this course will be in an advantageous position.
courses.learning_outcomes: By the conclusion of this course, students should be able to recall the names and thematic concerns of the contemporary writers studied. Indeed, they should be able to describe in some detail the issues that emerge from a close reading of the set texts. More engaged students will be able to compare and contrast the concerns of the various writers studied. Those fully engaged with the course will be able to go on to theorize the significance of such concerns to African literature and world literature at large.
courses.course_syllabus:
Module 1 Djibouti

Following a week giving the historical and political context of Waberi’s short novel In the United States of Africa (2009), this module goes on to think of the novel as a moment of counter-discursive resistance writing. As such, Edward Said’s (borrowed) notion of (hegemonic/colonial) discourse and Helen Tiffin’s notion of postcolonial counter-discourse will prove to be fundamental concepts of study.

Module 2 Mozambique

Again, following a short history of the struggle for independence and the subsequent civil war that has plagued the post-colonial generations of Mozambique, this module reads Mia Couto’s The Tuner of Silences (2012) in order to think through the idea of trauma. To this end, the notion of trauma as elucidated in the work of Kathy Caruth is examined.

Module 3 Angola

Ondjaki’s Granma Nineteen and the Soviet's Secret (2014) is read in the context of the Soviet intervention in Angola during the 1970s and 1980s. Here, though, critical attention is given to the role played by children in building the post-colonial state.

Module 4 South Africa

The final module of the course reads Lauren Beukes’s science fiction novel Zoo City (2010) in the context of the radical political changes in South Africa since 1990. The main discussion point here is the extent to which one can claim that the genre of science fiction is a product of its time of composition or, put another way, the extent to which science fiction is rooted to a political reality.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Assessment is continuous for the duration of the course. Therefore, formal feedback will be given to students on assessment tasks 1-3 (ie. the two essays and class presentation). Feedback on assessment task 4 (weekly contribution to class discussion) will take the form of direct engagement in the class discussion.

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: The London Novel
courses.description: This course examines the various ways in which London has been represented in a selection of diverse contemporary novels. Through both the close-reading of specific passages from the set novels and a general engagement with secondary theoretical material, it will become clear that the city continues to be represented in many different ways. From this observation emerges the realization that London is in fact, and has always been, an assemblage of very different Londons. It is this important observation that leads to the key conclusion of the course – no act of representation can ever fully capture its object of enquiry and, because of this, what has been chosen to be represented is always the product of a political decision.
courses.learning_outcomes: By the conclusion of this course, students should be able to recall some of the different ways in which London is represented in the contemporary novel and describe a number of factors leading to a particular representation of the city. More engaged students should be able to compare and contrast certain aspects of the different representations of London, while the most engaged students should be in a position to theorize London, and urban space more generally, as a complex of contradictory forces. In so doing, they will be able to reflect broadly on the significance of the inherent limits of representation in the context of literary studies.
courses.course_syllabus:
Module 1 High London / Low London

Through reading Ian McEwan’s novel Saturday, this module explores the very different Londons that are traversed by the characters of Perowne and Baxter. For Perowne, London is the bastion of learning, civilization, and – quite literally – life. For Baxter, London is a place in which he must survive. His violent and criminal ways paint a very different picture of the city in which Perowne lives. From this though, one is introduced to the complex interweave of learning and violence that is a constant present in the very fabric of civilization.

Module 2 Black London / White London

Sam Selvon’s novel, The Lonely Londoners, gives an intimate portrait of the first-wave immigrant experience of London. It is an image of the city that stands in stark contrast to that held by the native population. The way in which such communities work quietly and unseen beneath the daily operations of the city throw into sharp relief the very different London enjoyed by those native to the city. In this way, this module discusses issues of race and power in the city.

Module 3 Old London / New London

Penelope Lively’s novel, City of the Mind, gives entryway to the thoughts and speculations of a London architect who is responsible for redeveloping the so-called ‘edgelands’ of London. In addition to prompting questions over the significance of the complex temporalities at play in the London cityscape, this novel also demands that one take a position on the nostalgia vs progress debate that such redevelopment inevitably encourages. In doing so, this module introduces the notion of the neoliberal city.

Module 4 Real London / Unreal London

The course concludes with Neil Gaiman’s Neverwhere, a magic realist novel that renders literal a ‘London below.’ It is a novel that stresses the banality of day-to-day.

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Introduction to Computational Literary Studies
courses.description: For the last one hundred years or so, the respected literary critic was one who conducted a patient, private, close reading of an inevitably small number of texts. Today, due to the rampant digitization of hundreds of thousands of texts and radical developments in the accessibility of statistical analysis packages and platforms, the literary critic has been emancipated from working in only this way. This course introduces you to the field of computational literary analysis, which is to say a new way of engaging literary texts that takes advantage of such developments. By way of practice-based learning, you will learn to use the basic functionality of R – the leading language and platform for statistical computing and graphics in the humanities – in order to ask very different questions of literature to those that you typically learn to ask on an English literature programme. Importantly, the answers that you receive to such novel questions might just surprise you...
courses.learning_outcomes: By the end of the course, you should be able to use R in a meaningful way to analyse and critique literary texts. You should be familiar with the basic architecture and commands of R. As such, you will be able to import texts from various sources and understand the importance of suitably preparing texts for computational analysis. In addition to this, you will be able to conduct a number of statistical operations on literary texts that will expose latent structures or relations resident within a (set of) text(s).
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Understanding the debate around computational literary analysis

2. Introduction to major works of computational literary analysis

3. Understanding the R platform

4. Introduction to the R coding language

5. Introduction to importing texts and understanding various types of data structure in R

6. Understanding how to perform computational analyses (of various kinds) in R

7. Introduction to the visual presentation of data in R

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Ekphrasis: Encounters between Verbal and Visual Arts
courses.description: This course will study literature that represents visual arts or, ekphrasis. The term ‘ekphrasis’ can be broadly defined as verbal representation of visual arts and has become a vibrant field of study for a few decades. We will look at some most famous ekphrastic texts from the beginning of Western literature to this day, focusing on poems evoking either actual or imaginary artworks, but branching out to ekphrasis in fiction and new media as well. In the process, we will reflect on the evolution of the term ‘ekphrasis’ from a rhetorical device to a site of rivalry and on to a mode of encounter between the verbal and visual medium. The course will explore interactions of multiple media while foregrounding characteristics of each medium.

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Digital and Documentary Poetry
courses.description: This course introduces students to the history and methods of documentary poetry, focusing on both critical appreciation and creative practice, and offering opportunities to conduct their own practice-based creative research. Documentary poems represent a public event or historical moment by incorporating news accounts, photographs, legal records, or other archival materials into poetic writing. In this course, we’ll explore why documentary poetry is increasingly popular among contemporary poets who seek to make an impact in public conversations. The course traces the ways contemporary poets build on the tradition of documentary poetry, and asks how documentary practices are changing as public and private archives become more available through digitization. In order to explore new approaches to generating creative work ourselves, the course alternates several practicum-style skills workshops with writing workshops and seminar-style discussions of assigned readings. Over the course of the term, we’ll combine poetry-writing, visual arts, and literary journalism approaches with archival research and digital humanities skills, making our own original documentary poetic projects using compositional tools ranging from scissors and tape, to digital image manipulation software, to computational poetry programs. Previous experience with the course tools is not required; the only prerequisite is an interest in language, history, and how we remember our world together.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, students will be able to:

• Situate contemporary poetic works in relation to the 20th-century tradition of documentary poetics

• Conduct archival research using a variety of online resources

• Describe and purposefully use studio cutwork tools, creative word processing techniques, digital image manipulation software, and/or computer programming languages

• Articulate their own questions about the relationships among technology, history, poetry and public events

• Develop a body of creative work using documentary poetic strategies, and critically frame it with respect to the tradition of documentary poetics

• Effectively give and receive clear, constructive peer feedback in a workshop setting

| 4 | Public Erasures | Erasure and recomposition as a documentary poetic strategy |

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Shakespeare
courses.description: This course introduces students to the playwright William Shakespeare. By reading a number of Shakespeare's plays, drawn from the genres of comedy, history, tragedy and romance, students will achieve an understanding of Shakespeare's language, his modes of characterization, his methods of creating dramatic situations, and his representative themes. Students will also study the relationship of Shakespeare's scripts to their original Elizabethan and Jacobean performance contexts. Time permitting, attention will also be given to the performance history of Shakespearean drama and the continuing importance of that drama in twentieth-first century world theatre.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Students will have a deeper understanding of important universal human emotions and motivations as they are represented in the greatest poetry

2. Students will have a greater familiarity with the richness of the English language as shown in the work of its greatest poet..

3. Students will have a better understanding of one of the most important cultural epochs and icons of the English speaking world.

4. Students will be able to write better English in more organized presentation formats with use of evidence to support arguments.
courses.course_syllabus:
Important Shakespearean themes

Shakespeare’s treatment of passions such as love,ambition, revenge, honour and fortune, and of character and self-knowledge, in the context of Renaissance and European culture and tradition.

Shakespeare’s language

An introduction to the richness of Shakespeare’s poetry and verse forms (especially blank verse), with some reference to other literary artists of the era. How poetry works to suggest multiple meanings.

Culture and history

Background information on English and European politics, history, economics, culture, religion in the Renaissance and Reformation.

Writing better essays and written exercises

In the course written work you will learn to organize and present essays and written exercises more clearly.

Emphasis is placed on careful reading and understanding of selected passages. Summaries of the plays are provided. There may be some viewing of films.

courses.description: This course looks at how comparisons can be made between languages with respect to their sound systems, lexical-semantic structures, sentence patterns, and pragmatic properties. Through systematic analysis, students gain understanding from research findings in language typology, language universals, and language acquisition. This course focuses on the basic characteristics of English and Chinese, and some salient contrasts between them. The approach is largely descriptive without assuming prior knowledge of theoretical syntax. The course also considers how comparisons between languages may help students associated with problems of translation and language teaching/learning.

- conduct contrastive analyses of English and Chinese

- understand the theories in contrastive linguistics

- apply contrastive linguistics to language learning and teaching

courses.description: This course introduces psycholinguistics as it relates to language processing, acquisition, and development. We survey a range of topics such as language and the brain; real-time language processing and associated neuroimaging research; learning and memory; learner characteristics, age effects, and the critical period hypothesis; bi- and multi-lingualism; abnormal language development, language breakdown, and dyslexia; animal communication systems; which in turn shed light on mechanisms supporting human language and cognition.

courses.subject: ENGE

courses.description: This course introduces some major approaches as well as basic principles and tools in the analysis of texts. Concepts such as cohesion and coherence, relevance, context, and identity are drawn upon to analyze a range of discourses and text types in our contemporary society. Texts to be discussed include advertisements, news reports, interviews, political speeches, websites, book reviews, etc. The relevance of discourse analysis to foreign/second language teaching may also be considered.
courses.course_syllabus:
English 3670 is an introductory course on some fundamental issues in analyzing written and spoken texts. Given that
discourse analysis is concerned with the systematic and careful examination of a variety of texts, this course will be
organized according to the various ways linguists may interpret the notion of text.
This semester, we begin with a general review of discourse analysis as a field of linguistic study. Then, we follow that
discussion with an overview of various rhetorical and linguistic approaches to the analysis of texts as written discourse,
examining non-fiction (essays) and literary texts. Our stylistic analyses of writing includes the study of rhetorical aspects
(aims, purpose, rhetorical situation, style, discourse blocs, modes of development, voice/persona, tone, attitude, and
readability) and syntactic matters (i.e., lexical, phrasal, and clausal use). With an understanding of this approach, we use it to
analyze student-written essays; in addition, we consider what our findings may suggest about the texts and their writers,
with a view to identifying strategies for possible rewriting and revising.
Moving from text as written discourse, we adopt a broad notion of the term text as both written and spoken discourse. Primarily
using the work of text-linguists, we consider structures “beyond the sentence.” That is, we now view the idea of a text as
any passage, either spoken or written, of whatever length, that forms a unified whole; and we consider what makes a text
“good” or “successful” in terms of information flow (the way ideas are dispersed throughout a text) , coherence (global
concern that indicates a text is unified), and cohesion (local or surface concern that serve to link one idea and sentence to
the next one in a text). Again, once we complete some cohesion and information flow analyses, we look at practical ways
we might apply some of the key ideas in teaching and learning situations in Hong Kong.
Finally, we conclude with the notion of text as talking—oral exchanges. We will analyze naturally-occurring language in use, i.e.,
conversational analysis and pragmatics. To do so, we will cover such concepts such as the Gricean maxims and the
Cooperative Principle (rules and conditions which speakers abide by in effective or “happy” exchanges), implicature
(indirect meaning), speech acts (social act performed by the uttering of certain words), as well as associated phenomenon
(e.g., framing, turn-taking, overlap, interruption, adjacency pairs, etc. ). Our study of text as talk will enable us to explore
how and why people “do” things with words, sometimes successfully and sometimes not.
By the end of the course, we hope to have a better understanding of how discourse analysis reveals to us the intricacies of a
text as well as enhances our knowledge of how such analysis can strengthen our abilities as language users—speakers and
writers.

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: History of the English Language
courses.description: This course presents an overview of the origins and development of the English language from its earliest beginnings to the present day. The development of the language through its different stages is outlined: Old English, Middle English, Early Modern English, Present Day English. The influence of the social and historical background is exemplified throughout the course. The positive values of English as an international language are compared with the dangers of linguistic and cultural imperialism.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. A good knowledge of the broad outlines of the history of English.
2. Some understanding of the nature of linguistic change.
3. A knowledge of the major grammatical changes that have taken place in English, particularly the shift from synthetic to analytic and from OV to VO ordering.
4. A knowledge of the rich history of lexical change in English and its implications for the contemporary
structure of English vocabulary.
5. A strong sense of the social context of language in general and of English in particular..
6. An understanding of how has become a global language .

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Gender and Language
courses.description: This course provides an introduction to the relationship between gender and language use. Drawing from empirical and theoretical studies in sociolinguistics, psycholinguistics, and discourse analysis, this course addresses a range of issues. Examples of key issues include the acquisition of gender-differentiated language, gender and conversational interaction (e.g. extralinguistic constructions of gender or politeness, hedging or interruptions), sexism in language, gender images, and the relationships among language, gender, and other social constructs such as class, culture, and ethnicity.

Social and Linguistic Changes in Wo/men’s Speech
Gender Differentiation, Quantitative Sociolinguistics, and Social Networks
Conversational Interaction
Development of Gender-Appropriate Speech
Gender and Language Change
Sexism in Language Use

courses.description: This web-enhanced course is designed for students in all Faculties with recent or current international experience (study abroad, international exchange, volunteering, service-learning, internships, educational travel, work or residence abroad). courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Lenses into Language: Variation and Change
courses.description: There are two constant properties of language: variation and change. Languages vary in form across geographic space and social groups, and linguistic forms evolve over time, adapting to the society in which they are embedded. It makes sense to study these together because of their intricate links: if a language undergoes different transformations in different areas or subgroups, then variation results. As such, studying language change can help us to understand variation, and the nature of linguistic variation provides evidence as to how language changes. The course will focus on variation and change as a window to understanding the nature of language. It will cover topics related to these two properties such as language attitudes, historical change, and language contact. A sizeable number of case studies will be drawn from English. To strengthen the links between theoretical knowledge and practice, students will work hands-on with sociolinguistic data and attempt to analyze them using the framework of language variation and change.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students will be able to…

1. Demonstrate a clear conception of the theories in the sociolinguistic study of language variation and change.
2. Carry out basic analysis on linguistic varieties, especially those involving English elements, with a focus on variation and change, and
3. Explore various sociolinguistic phenomena using theoretical and methodological tools in a wide range of contexts.

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Bilingualism: Cognition and Society
courses.description: The rise of English as a global language lights the fuse for bilingualism (and multilingualism). This course aims to introduce theories and research findings concerning bilingualism and related phenomena. Bilingualism is both individual and societal. The first half of the course focuses on bilingual development within individuals. Topics include bilingual language development, factors affecting bilingual acquisition, bilingualism and aging, and cognitive advantages conferred by being bilinguals. The second half of the course turns to societal bilingualism. It will examine issues concerning language use, policymaking, and bi/multilingual education in different regions around the world, including but are not limited to Canada, Sweden, Singapore, and Hong Kong. This course will be of interests to students who are keen on linguistics and literacy development, language education, cognitive science, and developmental psychology.
courses.learning_outcomes:
The overall aim of the course is to enable you to understand how bilingualism affects individuals and societies. In more details, the course aims:

• To introduce you to up-to-date knowledge of key topics in bilingualism

• To enhance your understanding of the implications of bilingualism at individual and societal levels

• To develop your intellectual and critical-thinking abilities in discussing bilingualism issues in and out of class

As a result of this course, you should be able to demonstrate achievement of the following learning outcomes:

• To be able to discuss theories and findings pertinent to bilingualism research

• Understand common methods and techniques used in investigating bilingual language use

• Connect your personal experience in bilingual language development with societal bilingualism at large
courses.course_syllabus:
Myths of bilingualism - To define and introduce bilingualism scientifically and debunk certain false assumptions related to bilingual individuals

Bilingual memory - To introduce how bilingual memory works

Cognitive effects - To describe some cognitive benefits of being bilingual

Bilingualism and aging - To explore other lifelong consequences of bilingualism such as the delay of dementia

Bilingualism in changing societies - To explore how bilingualism affects societies at large

Bilingualism in different parts of the world - To infuse a regional as well as a global perspective into the study of bilingualism. Specific foci include Hong Kong, Singapore, Sweden, and the USA. Implications to education and bilingual language policy are the emphases.

Sign bilingualism - To introduce and raise awareness of sign bilingualism as a cross-modality type of bilingualism

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Methods in Applied Linguistics Research
courses.description:
This course provides an undergraduate-level overview of research methods within the field of applied linguistics. It provides students with vital skills necessary for designing, conducting, and evaluating research projects centered on language use and communication in real-world contexts, in anticipation of research endeavors like their final year or capstone projects. Participants will be introduced to research paradigms and principles tailored to applied linguistics, in addition to various research methodologies. These encompass quantitative methods like experiments and corpus-based studies, as well as qualitative approaches such as case studies and ethnographic research. The course places a particular emphasis on the practical application of these methods within the realm of applied (English) linguistics.

The course delves into an extensive array of data collection techniques commonly employed in applied linguistics research, including surveys, narrative studies, ethnographic observations, and corpus analysis. Through class activities, students will develop the skills needed to select the most suitable methods for their research questions, construct data collection instruments, and efficiently manage and analyze data sets. The course covers data analysis techniques encompassing both quantitative and qualitative methods. Students will have the opportunity to analyze quantitative data using statistical software and interpret the results, as well as to develop skills in the analysis of qualitative data, employing methods like thematic analysis and critical analysis. Several hands-on activities will be provided to encourage students to actively interact with and better grasp the concepts.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completing the course, students will be able to:

1. Explain the fundamental concepts and specific methods relevant to research in applied linguistics.
2. Analyze both qualitative and quantitative data, enabling them to confidently participate in and carry out independent research projects in the realm of applied linguistics.
3. Engage critically with and evaluate published research within the field of applied linguistics.
4. Analyze the uses, advantages, and limitations of various research designs employed in applied linguistics.

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Reading in English as a second language
courses.description: This course is designed to help undergraduate students understand the underlying processes involved in reading in English as a second language. The course will begin with fundamental theories on cognitive processes of first and second language reading, such as process models and component models. The course then reviews various components of second language reading, such as working memory, background knowledge (schema), and L2 linguistic knowledge (vocabulary and grammar). In addition, this course will invite students to discuss how to better utilize English reading to promote the development of English proficiency, with particular attention to tasks and technology use.

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Acquisition of English Phonology
courses.description: This course examines the first and second language acquisition of English phonetics and phonology, with a focus on various linguistic and extralinguistic processes and factors that impact acquisition. The impact of social factors such as identity and peer group networks on acquisition and use of different phonological features is also discussed. The course also examines accent and intelligibility, specifically in relation to stereotyping in the media. The course concludes with a discussion of the phonological features of the English spoken in Hong Kong.

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Professional Internship in English Studies
courses.description:
This internship course is designed to bridge students' academic studies with real-world professional experience, offering a unique opportunity to apply classroom knowledge in a practical work environment. By integrating academic theories, practices, and skills with workplace applications, students will gain hands-on experience and deepen their understanding of how English is used in professional settings.

Students are required to complete a minimum of 200 hours of full-time or part-time work at either local or international organizations where English is used for internal and external communication. While the department provides a range of pre-approved host organizations, students may also propose self-found internships, subject to the approval of the course leader.

To prepare for the recruitment process, students must attend all the workshops organized by Course leader and two mandatory workshops from the Career Planning and Development (CPDC) from the Office of Student Affairs, CUHK. This course ultimately fosters critical reflection on the relevance and effectiveness of classroom learning in professional contexts, equipping students with valuable skills for their future careers.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Demonstrate initiative in securing a relevant internship that aligns with the field of English Studies.
2. Describe and explain the structure and operations of the host organization, offering insights into its core functions.
3. Analyse workplace practices observed at the host organization, and assess their effectiveness by applying theories, concepts, and skills gained from prior coursework.
4. Critically reflect on the overall internship experience, including task performance, and propose creative solutions to any challenges encountered during the placement.
5. Evaluate the role of English as a global language within the host organization, and how it influences communication and operations.
6. Cultivate and refine professional competencies, skills, and attributes in a real-world workplace environment.

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: AI and Language
courses.description: In this course, students will delve into the relationship between artificial intelligence (AI) and human language. The course will primarily focus on English, while also challenging students to think critically about the relevance of the course material to their own languages or languages of interest. The course takes a multi-faceted approach, combining lectures, presentations, and hands-on activities to equip students with a solid understanding of AI fundamentals. As the course progresses, students will explore how computers process and generate human language, as well as how AI can be used to analyze language data. Ultimately, they will critically evaluate various AI-based techniques, while applying them to investigate key questions about human language. The course curriculum includes modules on language and computers, learner corpora, text preprocessing, speech-to-text, data visualization, and more.

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Digital Literacy as Social Practice
courses.description: Recognizing how technology has dramatically revolutionized not only the way we learn but also the way we work, communicate and interact with one another, this course examines diverse digital literacies that have become critical for agentive participation in the new social order. As people move fluidly across digitally-mediated spaces, how they negotiate their linguistic and semiotic resources shapes the way they construct their identities, acquire knowledge, and expand their social networks. Drawing on New Literacy Studies, this course demonstrates how digital literacy is not a neutral, technical competence, and that digital practices develop within broader social, political, and cultural contexts. Online spaces are circumscribed by competing and colluding ideologies, shaping new forms of inequality and social fragmentation. To respond to these issues, this course discusses the need to develop both functional and critical digital literacies to navigate and transform an increasingly technologized world.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students will have been able to:
• understand how technology has reshaped social, political, and economic contexts
• explore how social media constructs new modes of inclusion and exclusion
• develop strategies for identifying legitimate knowledge and forms of disinformation online
• examine the ideologies embedded in the design of various online spaces, and
• recognize how digital literacies range from the functional to the critical.

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Language and the Internet
courses.description: What happens to language when it goes online? Is the internet bad for the English language? Is online communication changing our relationships with others? Will emoji become a new language? This course examines the relationship between language and the internet. It explores how people use language on the internet as well as how new technologies are changing the ways we write and communicate. Internet platforms covered in this course include “traditional” ones such as email and discussion forums, and recent social media such as Facebook, Instagram, and YouTube. Key research methods and theories of the emerging area of Internet Linguistics are also discussed. The course concludes by looking into the future of the English language on the increasingly globalized and multilingual internet.
courses.course_syllabus:
Tentative course syllabus:

* Week 1: Language in the Digital Age: An introduction – This lecture considers changes in contemporary life; how language is central in life as well as contemporary changes; and how written language has always been shaped and affected by technological changes in history.
* Week 2: A linguistic perspective of computer-mediated communication (CMC): The case of email – This lecture explores the questions *Why should we study language online?* *What is the scope of Internet Linguistics?* *How can we study the language of asynchronous CMC (e.g. email)?*
* Week 3: Linguistic features of asynchronous and synchronous CMC; Computer-mediated Communication as Persistent Conversations: Instant Messaging and Mobile Texting – This lecture first considers first consider conversational features of chatrooms and instant messaging. Concepts and methods for analyzing conversational features in online chat data will also be outlined**.**
* Week 4: The language of Web 2.0 spaces: Blogging and self-publishing practices (weblogs, status reports and Twitter) This lecture defines the scope of Web 2.0 and how it is related to the study of language. It also introduces methods of analyzing the language of weblogs or similar media through content analysis, coding and stance analysis.
* Week 5: The language of social media – This lecture explores the affordances of social media, the functions of language on social media, and the common discourse processes on social media.
* Week 6: Multimodal discourses and visual literacies – This lecture dresses the questions of *Why should we be interested in visual images in the study of internet linguistics?* And *How are words and images (verbal and visual) combined to form a coherent discourse online?*
* Week 7: Linguistic construction of identities online - This lecture considers how identities are constructed through language in online spaces. Key topics include the interplay between new media and life; Defining identity; Linguistic performance of identity online: Nicknames, gender, code-switching.
* Week 8: Globalization and the Multilingual Internet - This lecture discusses the status of English and other languages on the internet, forms of multilingualism online, multilingual practices on Web 2.0, and new trends of multilingualism online
* Week 9: Educational implications of computer-mediated writing - In this lecture, we consider the following questions: Does computer-mediated discourse threaten language standards? (How) can popular CMC be incorporated into formal education? Will “Netspeak” eventually replace existing varieties of language? What are the future trends in the study of CMD?
* Week 10: Online Crimes and Forensic Linguistics – This lecture discusses and illustrates the interplay of digital discourse and what is commonly referred to as *online crimes or cybercrimes*. It first defines the scope of cybercrime and forensic linguistics. It will focus on the application of author profiling and authorship attribution in selected cases of cybercrime.

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Data Science and Statistical Approaches to Analyzing English Data
courses.description: The power of data is recognizable – now more than ever. Data has always existed and now has taken center stage in the world and its industries, especially in recent years. In this course, you will learn how to leverage your data, that is, learn how to transform it into something meaningful and useful for scientific research. Building on your prior knowledge of digital literacy, statistics, and programming, we will delve deeper into contemporary topics and approaches in Data Science and statistics as it relates to the English language. Unlike other data science and statistics courses, this course is designed for students who have already the foundations of data science but hope to specialize in, conduct research on, or create projects related to the English language and linguistics. Following a topical approach, we will explore more advanced topics in data management, processing, statistics, and data visualization using the programming tool R, covering trending topics like dimensionality reduction, natural language processing, and machine learning and how these are applied to the study of English. You will gain a contextualized understanding of statistics and practical skills for tackling core data scientific challenges relevant to the field.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, you should be able to…

1. Gain a well-rounded understanding of Data Science and statistics as it relates to language (especially the English language) and linguistics,
2. Make use of data science tools and techniques for managing and interrogating raw, derived, observed datasets in English,
3. Possess practical skills for handling complex datasets for quantitative research in the study of language and sociolinguistic phenomena.

Being able to analyze linguistic and textual data is a highly useful skill for in academic work, in the private sector, and government-related work. The course intends to build on your prior knowledge of digital literacy, statistics, and programming and delves deeper into contemporary topics in Natural Language Processing (NLP) and data science as it relates to linguistics and the social sciences (e.g., anthropology, history, psychology, and sociology). It is designed for students who hope to explore language data using NLP techniques. Students will get first-hand experience working with state-of-the-art software in corpus linguistics, NLP, and data science (i.e., Python, CasualConc). They will learn contextualized techniques to parse and collate information from text-rich documents, such as corpora as well as social media. This course assumes that students have a rudimentary knowledge of Python, linguistics, and data analysis.
