courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Major Author(s)
courses.description: An intensive study of the life, the imaginative character, and the works of a single author or authors who have played major roles in the development of Western literature. Authors studied may vary from year to year. Offerings with different subtitles can be taken up for credit, up to a maximum of two times.
courses.learning_outcomes:
The goals of this course are:

1. To examine some of the key works in the twentieth century, analyzing their thematic and formal aspects and innovations.

2. To evaluate the importance of the major writers studied.

3. To explore the links between literary issues and changing sociohistorical conditions in the twentieth century.

4. To examine the subtle shift from modernism to postmodernism in the texts studied.

5. To reflect on the links between the works, our own lives, and the Hong Kong context

6. To develop further skills in critical and creative thinking, and oral and written communication.

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Love, Death, and God in English Renaissance Poetry
courses.description: This course aims to cover some of the key poetic texts of the English Renaissance in order to explore two of their ongoing preoccupations: love and death. This course will explore the ways these texts use two aspects of the human experience to consider the nature of what lies beyond the human: the ideal, the metaphysical, and God. Where the love poetry of the period frequently idealizes the beloved into a kind of a divinity, Renaissance poetry which ruminates on the nature of mortality frequently does so under the eyes of a God who is, by turns, vengeful and merciful, benevolent and indifferent. While this course is thematic, it also covers many of the formal preoccupations of English Renaissance poetry. Some of these include: imitation, pastoral, paradox, metaphor, and epic form. Poems by Spenser, Sidney, Shakespeare, Donne, Herbert, and Milton will be covered. These are some of the most important figures in English literature, but whose language and chronological distance make them daunting to many students. This course will not only make them more accessible, but it will teach students methods of close reading which will give them the skills to read other such difficult texts in the future.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course a student will have:

i) A greater understanding of notoriously daunting poetic texts which are nevertheless central to the English literary canon.

ii) Thought deeply upon the themes of love and death, and explored why, in Renaissance poetry, these most human of experiences are used to intimate that which lies beyond the human.

iii) Considered these highly influential poems in a thematic way so as to allow for and encourage comparisons with literature of later time periods.

iv) Gained a broader knowledge of one of the most important periods in English literature.

v) Acquired techniques of close reading by which to methodically analyse complex and difficult texts.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1: Milton, “Lycidas”: Death, Love, and Prayer [Imitation; pastoral; the career of the poet]

Week 2: Spenser, Shepheardes Calender (selections): To Have Loved and Lost [Pastoral; tradition; the edited text; Petrarchanism]

Week 3: Spenser, Shepheardes Calender (selections): To Have Loved and Gained [Sonnet sequences; metaphor; the rhetoric of love]

Week 4: Spenser, The Faerie Queene (Book 1, Canto 1): Epic and Allegory [Redcrosse Knight, Errour; allegory; the epic poet]

Week 5: Sidney: A Defense of Poetry (selections): Poetry and the Divine [The idea(l) and form]

Week 6: Sidney, Astrophil and Stella (selections): “What may words say” [Sonnets sequences; inwardness, courtly love; writing love]

Week 7: Shakespeare, Sonnets (from 1-126): Poetry and Immortality (I) [Petrarchan tradition; imitation and subversion; patronage; inwardness; epideictic poetry]

Week 8: Shakespeare, Sonnets (from 127-154): Poetry and Immortality (II) [Black/fair; lying; love and resentment]

Week 9: Donne, Songs and Sonnets (selections): Paradoxes of Nothing: Love and Death [Metaphor and love poetry; metaphysical poetry]

Week 10: Donne: Holy Sonnets (selections), “Good Friday Riding Westward”, “Hymn to God the Father”: Faith in God, Fear of God [Faith and doubt; earthly and divine love]

Week 11: Herbert: The Temple (selections): God of Judgement, God of Love [Paradox; the conceit]

Week 12: Milton: “On the Morning of Christ’s Nativity,” “On Shakespeare,” “Sonnet 16,” “Lycidas” [The poet as prophet; the poetic career; the poetic self; Paradise Lost]

Week 13: The Renaissance Reborn: Synoptic Lecture

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Reading Paradise Lost
courses.description:
This course focuses on a single, seminal work of English literature: Milton’s Paradise Lost. The length and complexity of the work make it ideally suited for the kind of focused consideration that this course would provide. Some of the themes covered will be: the idea of literary imitation; the poet as prophet; the nature of sin; how to write about the ineffable; the power of persuasive language. These themes (and many more) are central to Paradise Lost, but are equally the concern of other texts by Milton as well as other writers in the period. Where possible, these additional works will be considered in order to shed light on Paradise Lost and to flesh out its complexities. Paradise Lost has also been the subject of a wide variety of literary critical approaches – reader response, new historicist, psychoanalytic – and these too will be considered over the duration of the course.

There will also be a significant emphasis placed on reading aloud in this course. Typically, a lecture will contain an hour of literary analysis from me followed 45 minutes of reading aloud performed by me and the students. Students will be allocated characters in the poem to read in preparation for each lecture.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course a student will have:

i) A greater understanding of the most important epic poem in English.

ii) Considered this poem in a thematic way so as to allow for and encourage comparisons with literature of later time periods.

iii) Gained a broader knowledge of one of the most important periods in English literature.

iv) Acquired techniques of close reading by which to methodically analyse other complex and difficult texts.

courses.description: This course will investigate some critical concepts and literary theories within the context of East/West comparative literature. courses.learning_outcomes:

Students will be able to take advantage of their own cultural backgrounds in literary studies, to analyze topics in East/West literatures in a cross-cultural perspective, and to obtain a broad view of literature across cultural and national differences.

Students will be able to read deeply literary texts from both Eastern and Western cultural traditions toward comprehending their theoretical and practical implications, and to interpret them coherently in relation to the topics addressed in this course.

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Reading Dante’s Inferno
courses.description: This course will focus on one seminal work of Western literature: Dante’s Inferno. The length and richness of this work make it ideally suited for the focussed, semester-long consideration this course will provide. Some of the themes covered will be: the concept of Hell, the nature of Sin, the poet as prophet, the medieval understanding of the cosmos, the uses of allegory. These themes not only exist in the Inferno, but will be substantiated and extrapolated by references to many of Dante’s other works, including Vita Nuova, Monarchia, and the Convivio. These other works, together with details of Dante’s political life, biography, and historical period will be brought to bear on the text as we read through it. Emphasis will also be put on the various literary critical approaches which have been taken to the text, including historicist, feminist, and psychoanalytic. Students are encouraged to take ENGE4120 Reading Paradise Lost either before or after taking this course.
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Students will acquire knowledge of a key text of Western literature, and the various themes it explores: sin, politics, poetry, pilgrimage, the afterlife, God.
• Students will learn to analyse a complex allegorical text written at a time and place historically and cultural remote form our own.
• Students will have acquired techniques of close reading by which they can methodically analyse other challenging texts.
• Students will critique the views of literary critics who have analysed the poem in order to come to their own understanding.
• Students will gain a critical understanding of the poem from a thematic perspective to facilitate comparison with other texts.

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Advanced Creative Writing Workshop
courses.description: This course is the Creative Writing Stream’s advanced writing workshop elective. In this course, you will hone your skills in a particular genre (poetry, fiction, life writing, or dramatic writing) by receiving sustained, detailed feedback from a workshop leader and your peers in a focused, intimate setting. Our small class size will allow us to study and practice the techniques of creative writing with a rigor and intensity impossible in a larger lecture course. You will practice drafting and revision strategies; learn to give and receive constructive feedback; and produce a substantial, revised, and well-polished portfolio of your creative writing. You will also learn professionalization skills including preparing your work both for publication and for further study in the field of creative writing. Our main texts will be each other’s writing, but we will also read and discuss craft essays and published creative works, and become familiar with the several main models of creative writing workshops, their histories, and the communities with which they are associated. You do not need to feel “advanced” in your writing to take this writing-intensive course, but you must have taken at least one course in the Department’s Creative Writing Stream, and you must submit a writing sample for pre-approval by the instructor.
courses.enrollment_requirement: At least one of the following: ENGE3260 Creative Writing; ENGE3290 Reading and Writing Short Stories; ENGE3360 Special Topics in Creative Writing; OR ENGE3370 Writing Hong Kong.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Specific student learning outcomes expected from this course are:

Students will be able to:

* Identify and describe the major models of creative writing workshops and their historical contexts and associated literary communities.
* Identify, describe, and more confidently use the artistic and rhetorical devices that constitute the building blocks of effective creative writing.
* Explain the major stages of drafting, and articulate their own individual writing and revision process.
* Read and discuss creative writing and literary texts with greater precision and insight.
* Assess and sharpen their own creative writing in response to written and oral critique.
* Produce a carefully revised, polished portfolio of creative works accompanied by a critical reflection situating their portfolio in the context of contemporary works in their chosen genre.

courses.description:
This course is offered to those students who are selected each year to represent the University in the Chinese Universities Shakespeare Festival. As such, it will be highly selective: only five students will be invited to sign up. Of these students, three will be actors, and two will be assistant directors. All undergraduates in the department will be invited to audition in mid November.
By the end of this course, students would have learned the fundamentals of Shakespearean stagecraft, voice production, creating a character, and expressive movement and gesture. They would also have learned the basic principles of technical aspects of production such as set, lighting, and costume design. Students will also have gained intimate knowledge of at least 3 Shakespearean plays which will be studied from both a literary critical and dramaturgical perspective.
Students will also have to submit an analytical essay which asks them to utilise what they have learned in the experience of putting on a play for production, and to reflect upon that process.
Offerings with different subtitles can be taken up for credit, up to a maximum of two times.
courses.learning_outcomes:

to analyze dramatic texts as performance texts.
to create and perform a character on stage.
to use their voice and body to communicate to an audience.
to utilise theoretical understanding of a dramatic text in performance.
to articulate English more effectively.

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Linguistic Landscape: People, Place, and the City
courses.description: We are surrounded by language. The visibility of languages in the city tells the history, identity, and culture of the people and place. This interdisciplinary course engages students in using linguistic landscape as a framework to examine the role of displayed language in the construction of places, identities, and ideologies. Linguistic landscape studies linguistic, sociocultural, political, spatial, educational, and communicative meanings, among others, of the language displayed in place. In this course, students will explore languages used in multiple spaces such as street,shop/supermarket, hospital, MTR station, school/university, museum, and restaurant and analyze them from interdisciplinary perspectives, drawing on linguistic, sociological, anthropological, communication, spatial, political, and educational/pedagogical theories. The course focuses on engaging students in fieldwork to collect the images/photos of the language displayed in city spaces and analyze them in class by taking multiple theoretical perspectives. The topics of discussion include multilingualism, multimodality, identity, place, people, and policy in linguistic landscape.
courses.learning_outcomes:
On completion of the course, the students are expected to:
• develop a critical understanding about various theories of linguistic landscape.
• explore, observe, and collect languages used in city spaces.
• analyze linguistic landscape data from an interdisciplinary perspective.
• apply linguistic landscape theories to analyse the interrelationship between people, place and language.

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Educational Linguistics
courses.description: Educational Linguistics is the field of study that focuses on the application of linguistics in education. This course aims at engaging students in understanding and examining how knowledge about linguistics and language use can be applied to address various educational issues such as effective language teaching/learning and policy-making in diverse contexts. The major topics of the course include: linguistics in the classroom, multilingual/multiliteracy education, language awareness, translanguaging pedagogies, and language education policy. In addition, the course focuses on how linguistic, racial/ethnic, and cultural diversities can be understood and addressed in education. Students will read and discuss major theories, models, and activities to explore the application of linguistics in education in different world contexts, including Hong Kong.
courses.learning_outcomes:
On completion of the course, the students are expected to:

* Explore the application of linguistics in education.
* Analyse the application of different linguistic theories, models, and activities in language education.
* Examine language education policy and practices in diverse world contexts.
* Interrogate linguistic, cultural, and racial/ethnic diversities and their implications in language education.

courses.description: This course focuses on a contemporary approach to discourse analysis, Critical Discourse Analysis (CDA), which investigates real language data from a social and ideological perspective. The course aims to provide students with the analytical toolkit for understanding ideologies and power relations in different discourse contexts. Major research methods of CDA are illustrated through a range of authentic spoken and written texts such as political speeches, classroom interaction, broadcast news reports, advertisements, and websites.

courses.description: This course provides a broad introduction to general linguistics and the fundamental properties of human language shared by all language systems. It includes a survey of phonological, morphological, syntactic, and semantic structures of language, thus enabling students to investigate established theoretical premise for the linguistic description of natural languages and describe general grammatical properties of language universals in the light of the theory established. This course also equips students with some analytical tools and techniques for linguistic analysis and provides practice in using these scientific ways to discover the organizing principles underlying a language.

courses.learning_outcomes: By the end of this course, students should be able to grasp the basic concepts of linguistics in terms of its structure and uses and the relationship between them. More importantly, students are, if they wish to, expected to incorporate these concepts into further pursuit of linguistic studies.

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: What is Fiction?
courses.description: What are the consequences of a world in which AI-generated content, fake news, and social media have increasingly eroded the boundary between truth and falsity, and how do these consequences impact the study and understanding of literature, the imaginative medium par excellence? This course will explore these questions by examining the concept of fiction, how it is manifested in various genres and forms, and what role it plays for writers and readers in contemporary society. Tracing its historical development, we will investigate the concept of fiction as a crucial dimension across time in various communicative contexts, including but not limited to literary discourse. Through analyzing examples ranging from novels and storytelling to non-fictional genres, including autobiographical discourses, documentaries, social media, and political speeches, students will learn how to evaluate and appreciate dominant perspectives within fiction theory, including panfictionalism, similarism, separationism, speech act theory, and possible worlds semantics. Students interested in gaining the theoretical and analytical tools to understand the many uses of fiction, its roles, effects, and potential consequences in contemporary society are welcome to join the course.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA English (Literary Studies) or MPhil English (Literary Studies)
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to:

* understand the historical development of different interpretations of fiction
* possess analytical tools to engage with the concept of fiction across various genres and forms.
* understand, evaluate, and appreciate dominant perspectives within fiction theory.
* possess the theoretical and historical background knowledge to understand what role fiction plays in contemporary debates on social media, fake news, and AI-generated content.
* use critical thinking and analytical skills related to the study of fictional discourse.

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Literature and Pedagogy
courses.description: This course focuses on the art of teaching literature in the classroom, and the subject will be studied from both a theoretical and a practical perspective. Students will learn about contemporary theories of pedagogy as well as practice conducting discussions of literary texts. Particular attention will be given to the English-as-a-second-language environment of Hong Kong, and the particular challenges and opportunities this presents.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA English (Literary Studies)
courses.learning_outcomes: To understand a range of pedagogical approaches to the teaching of literature, to learn ways of teaching English-language literature most successfully to Hong Kong students, to increase awareness of the dynamics of classroom interactions, to improve one’s ability to inspire students in the classroom.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course will take a specific, committed approach to the teaching of literature, one which uses the tools and concepts of literary stylistics and cognitive poetics. Very often, approaches to teaching literature, whether at the school or university level, are rather vague and pay little or no attention to the actual language of literary works. Students are often left rather puzzled as to what is expected of them and what they are meant to ‘get out’ of literary works. The stylistics and cognitive poetics approach to teaching literature gives a concrete orientation to literary pedagogy. It must always start from the students’ own spontaneous responses to a literary work, whether a poem, short story, novel or play. There can be no question of merely teaching students how to carry out some kind of ‘dry,’ pointless, linguistic description of a literary work. They must be led from their own experiences of a work on to a linguistic and, as we shall see, psychological analysis that helps them to see what it is in the work that gives rise to their own experiences of it. This linguistic and psychological analysis can then further enrich these experiences themselves and lead on to a further round of analysis. This cycle of experience and analysis can then be repeated until it is felt that the work in question has been adequately, or at least significantly, dealt with.

Clearly, if someone is to be equipped to carry out this kind of teaching, they must themselves have an adequate knowledge of stylistics and cognitive poetics. This course will therefore both teach this knowledge to its students and investigate how they themselves can then use it to teach their own students, actual or potential. Although stylistics is concerned with the linguistic details of texts, it is important to understand that it is concerned with far more than just that. It has developed over the last thirty or forty years into an exploration of how people read and respond to literary works. This exploration draws upon the tools of linguistics and psychology to see how our minds construct the imaginative worlds of literature. There is always far more to a novel or poem than just the language on the page, though that language is of course our starting point for constructing the novel or poem’s imaginative world and so does itself require close attention. Although this course will be using tools drawn from linguistics and psychology, no particular background in either of these disciplines is presupposed or needed. All the three major forms of literary discourse, poetry, drama and fiction, will be dealt with.

A major question of pedagogy is always of course to what extent a teacher should make explicit to their students the knowledge base that they themselves are using in their teaching, that is, just how much of this knowledge base should made be explicit and how much should be left implicit in the actual teaching itself. The balance between explicit and implicit teaching will depend to a very large degree of course on the age and level of the pupils being taught. This issue will be continually addressed throughout the course and ample opportunity will be given for the course’s students to explore it in their mid-term and final papers, which will include options for designing teaching courses of various kinds. Another pedagogical issue that will be addressed is that of using the stylistic and cognitive poetics approaches to literature to combine second language learning with the study of literature in a second language. Second language students have a more explicit knowledge of the grammar of the language they are studying than mother tongue students and this itself is a great advantage in using the stylistic approach; above all, however, a stylistic and cognitive approach to literature in a second language offers great opportunities for deepening second language students’ knowledge of the second langue they are studying, English for example, and their appreciation of its grammatical, lexical and, through the study of poetic metre, even its phonetic subtleties.

The basic framework for the study of stylistics and cognitive poetics will be provided by a, freely available, Web based course designed and created by Professor Mick Short of the University of Lancaster. This is an interactive course with lots of exercises for students to do. It is important to grasp that doing stylistics is at least as much a matter of the practical analysis of texts as it is of theoretical exploration. Students will be able to work on the Web-based course in their own time. The classroom sessions will consists of lectures by the teacher that will go more deeply into the issues raised in the Web-based course, together with the practical analyses of texts selected by the teacher.. Students will be divided into small groups for the purpose of these analyses. The combination of in class, practical analysis and the interactive stylistic exercises in the on-line course should provide students with plenty of ideas and materials for developing teaching programmes and tools of their own.

courses.description: This course provides an in-depth study of developments in children's literature through an examination of some essential, central texts as well as recent books for children. The uses of fantasy and the educational aspects of books for children will be discussed, along with notions of childhood and the nature of children. Through close reading, students will be able to engage in critical techniques applicable to most literature, for the best texts for children satisfy sensitive adult readers too.

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Life Writing
courses.description: This course examines the genre of autobiography, one of the most popular forms of writing in the contemporary world. The course will cover such topics as the nature of memory, the reliable/unreliable narrator, public and private interpretations of life, and identification/identity in terms of such factors as race, class, gender, language, and culture. Students will become familiar with concepts such as autobiography, biography, narrative, memoirs, historiographic fiction, bildungsroman, and the blurring between truth and fiction in text.

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Science Fiction and Utopia
courses.description:
This course examines the political and social dimension of science fiction writing. It does so by interrogating the different forms of utopia and dystopia presented in a number of science fiction films and novels.

The course begins by tracing the concept of utopia back to its early literary origins in order to reveal its deeply political nature. Following this, we begin to think about the different forms of utopia and dystopia presented in science fiction writing, and begin to develop an understanding of utopia and dystopia as the product of a distinct critique of contemporary society.

To this end, the course critiques three main staging grounds of utopia in science fiction – society; time and space; and, the body.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA in English (Literature Studies) only.

courses.description: This course is an introduction to American Literature of the twentieth century. We will study a representative selection of novels, drama, film, and poetry, and discuss concepts such as nationalism/national identity, the frontier, the American Dream, democracy, gender and sexuality, race and ethnicity, and immigration. As we discover significant historical moments, artistic movements, and geographical locations in these texts, we will also trace the social, political, and cultural conditions from which they emerge. Figures studied will include (but are not limited to): F. Scott Fitzgerald, Langston Hughes, William Carlos Williams, Arthur Miller, Tennessee Williams, Lorraine Hansberry, Alfred Hitchcock, John Ford, Amiri Baraka, Allen Ginsberg, Toni Morrison, Tony Kushner, and Jhumpa Lahiri.

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Modernist Literature
courses.description: In this course, we will examine various modernist fiction, essays and poetry in order to understand not only the formal and innovative aspects of modernism, but also some of the historical and material conditions which propelled the literary movement of modernism into being in the first place. We will consider such wide-ranging historical issues as imperialism, modernity, war, and female emancipation, and see how these helped shape both the form and content of modernist literature. The course will involve extremely close reading of the texts, with the goals to re-introduce students to terminology useful in literary analysis, and to teach methods to analyze and understand the formal and technical complexities of literary modernism.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For TPG MA in English (Literary Studies)
courses.learning_outcomes:

2. Be able to describe the modernist movement from the multiple perspectives of material history, literary history and formal aesthetics.
3. Have acquired an understanding of the relationships between the texts studied, and between the texts and their contexts.
4. Have gained in-depth knowledge of the lives, literary methods and cultural perspectives of the three major authors studied: Virginia Woolf, T.S. Eliot and Joseph Conrad.

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Distant Readings
courses.description: In the context of a world that was beginning to understand the power of “big data,” Franco Moretti introduced the notion of “distant reading” to the field of literary studies. A method of literary scholarship that embraced the technological explosion at the end of the twentieth century, Moretti’s distant reading looked to transcend a literary studies that he thought of as dominated by the “theological exercise” of close reading – which is to say the “very solemn treatment of very few texts taken very seriously.” Distant reading attempted (attempts) to make sense of thousands of texts at the same time. It asks questions that only a survey of tens of thousands of texts can answer – how does the thematic concern of western literature change over the decades… or over the centuries? And not just the thematic concern of the canonical literature we all know, but all western literature (or as much of it as we can recover today!) Such questions cannot be answered by the individual scholar but, as Moretti understood, they can be answered with the aid of computation. This course introduces you to the debates provoked by Moretti’s ideas and then moves on to show you how distant reading is practiced today. By way of workshop and project-based learning, you will be introduced to the statistical analysis platforms that computational literary studies scholars use today. You will then learn how to use this software in order to generate your own distant readings of a corpus of texts.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA English (Literary Studies) or MPhil English (Literary Studies)
courses.learning_outcomes: By the end of the course, you should be able to understand the contentions and provocations of Moretti’s notion of “distant reading.” In addition to this, you should be able to use the statistical analysis platform, R, as a means of meaningfully analysing and critiquing literary texts. That is to say, you should be familiar with the basic architecture and commands of R to the extent that you are able to conduct your own distant reading on a corpus of texts.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Understanding the contentions and provocations of Moretti’s “distant reading”

2. Introduction to Moretti’s major works

3. Understanding the R platform

4. Introduction to the R coding language

5. Introduction to importing texts and understanding various types of data structure in R

6. Understanding how to perform computational analyses (of various kinds) in R

7. Introduction to the visual presentation of data in R

courses.title: Psycholinguistics
courses.description: The course will examine some linguistic, behavioural, and neural aspects of language and speech in an English-as-a-second/foreign-language (ESL/EFL) or English-related bilingual context. Selected issues in speech perception, language comprehension and language production as well as the intermediate stages that comprise the language of thought will be considered. Special attention will be given to some current, representative models of discourse comprehension and production and their relevance to second language teaching and learning.

courses.description: This course provides a survey of the relationship between social variables (e.g., age, gender, ethnicity, attitude, style, location, time, social status, power, politics, and network membership) and variations in language in use. Some key areas covered include language attitudes and choice, language maintenance and shift, code alternation, contact languages, standard and vernacular languages, language planning and policy, regional and social dialects, influences of age and gender on language in use, politeness theory, linguistic stereotyping, as well as culture and language. Sociolinguistic research methods are also introduced.

Singapore, the PRC, Japan, Malaysia, India, and the Philippines). By carrying out

speech communities, cultural contexts, genres/forms, notions of literacy, etc.

courses.description: The purpose of this course is to introduce definitions, theoretical issues, and empirical research on the topic of second language acquisition (SLA). To be more specific, the aims of this course are to help students 1) gain familiarity with key concepts in SLA research, as a basis for critically understanding and developing professional practices; 2) develop an awareness of and ability to critique and design empirical research on topics related to SLA; 3) build an expert and personally relevant understanding of theoretical and empirical issues in the field, including cognitive-interactionist and frequency-based perspectives of SLA and the roles of learner factors such as age, first language, and individual difference variables; 4) understand the relationship between theory, research, and classroom applications; and 5) achieve increased awareness of how a range of relevant research and research methods can be used for the development of their own teaching practices and research agenda in the Chinese/Asian contexts.

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Corpus Linguistics
courses.description: A corpus (plural corpora) is body of written text and/or transcribed speech which can serve as a basis for linguistic analysis and description. This course explores the ways in which corpora can be used to study the frequency and distribution of linguistic items, as well as collocations, keywords, and register variation. Most of the lectures are followed by a practical session, during which students gain hands-on experience in using the corpora and software demonstrated and/or discussed in the lectures. The corpora used include the International Corpus of English (ICE), the British National Corpus (BNC), the Chinese Learner English Corpus (CLEC), and many others. Students will learn how to use standard text retrieval software, including WordSmith, ICECUP, and WMatrix. The course is heavily computer-oriented, but no programming skills are required.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA English (Applied English Linguistics) or MPhil English (Applied English Linguistics)
courses.learning_outcomes:
you should be able to demonstrate achievement of the following learning outcomes:

- use standard corpus software and English language corpora in language research

- use standard statistical techniques to interpret quantitative data

- read primary sources critically and effectively

- understand the research techniques used in corpus linguistics
courses.course_syllabus:
the course aims:

- to enable you to become familiar with the range of English language corpora and software that is currently available

- to equip you with the skills necessary to manipulate and interpret quantitative data derived from a corpus

- to appreciate the applications of corpus linguistics in a wide range of sub-fields, including English language teaching

- in project work, to develop your ability to design and report a research project using a corpus

- in written work, to develop your ability to read and evaluate previous corpus-based research and techniques.

courses.title: Natural Language Processing for Applied Linguistics and Education
courses.description: This course provides a thorough introduction to common NLP techniques, focusing on how computers analyze, comprehend, produce, and process language. It incorporates a hybrid approach combining lecture segments, presentations, and hands-on activities to discuss how we can make use of various applications and programming codes (in Python) to facilitate research in (applied) linguistics and education. The modules that will be covered in the course include: introduction to language and computers, introduction to Python, preprocessing text, optical character recognition, speech to text, web scraping, frequency and n-gram, vector semantics and embeddings, part‑of‑speech tagging, constituency parsing, and dependency parsing. Crucially, students are expected to critically think about innovative ways to apply NLP techniques in (applied) linguistics and/or education.

courses.title: Evaluation and Testing
courses.description: This course examines the process of evaluation in second language learning. Evaluation refers to the systematic gathering of information for purposes of making value judgements about language learning programmes and the participants in these programmes. The methods of enquiry include observations, interviews, meetings, questionnaires, and testing. Public English proficiency examinations, both local and overseas, will be critically assessed. Key ideas in testing will be covered: validity and reliability; tests of global proficiency and of separate skills; particular problems with tests of listening and oral English; tests of communicative competence.

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: English for Specific Purposes
courses.description: This course will introduce students to the field of teaching English for specific purposes (ESP) by exploring the primary context for ESP teaching and research (academic institutions of higher education, the workplace, and professional institutions and organizations). The course will examine the main issues and concepts related to the field in terms of their historical and discipline-specific relevance. Topics include the concepts of learner needs, target situation analysis, authenticity, discourse community, genres, and specialist knowledge. The course will equip students with a better understanding of how to design language programmes to suit the needs of a specific group of learners.

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Second Language Teaching
courses.description: This course is designed to help students develop robust understanding about how instruction can facilitate second language acquisition. It begins with theories underlying implicit and explicit second language instruction. Then, various pedagogical approaches to second language grammar and vocabulary development are introduced, highlighting the differences between input-based and output-based instruction. In addition, this course reviews empirical findings on the effects of various pedagogical interventions on second language learning so that students can understand the importance of theoretically supported pedagogical approaches in second language teaching.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA English (Applied English Linguistics) or MPhil English (Applied English Linguistics)
courses.course_syllabus:
The nature of L2 knowledge - Implicit vs explicit/ declarative vs procedural knowledge of L2

Interaction in L2 classroom - Input hypothesis, Interaction approach, Output hypothesis, Focus on form, Task-based language teaching

The acquisition of grammar and vocabulary - Consciousness-raising task, processing instruction, presentation-practice-production, explicit grammar instruction, vocabulary learning from reading and from word-focused activities

Individual differences in L2 language classrooms - Cognitive and affective factors

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Discourse and Pragmatics
courses.description: This course examines language from pragmatic and discourse analytic perspectives. Topics include speech act theory, conversational implicature, cross-cultural pragmatics, and politeness theory. Other topics include conversation analysis, discourse structure and segmentation, cohesion, coherence, and discourse and intertextuality. Students will have the opportunity to examine samples of real life language employing the approaches to analysis presented in the course.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA English (Applied English Linguistics) or MPhil English (Applied English Linguistics)
courses.learning_outcomes:
1) By the end of this course, students will:

- have learnt the basic theoretical concepts of pragmatics and discourse analysis, how these relate to each other, and how they are to be applied to the practical business of analyzing naturally occurring discourse.
- have learnt about cohesion and coherence, conversational implicature, speech acts, politeness in discourse and social interaction, the ethnography of speaking and communication, and about conversation analysis and other forms of extended text analysis.
- have been well grounded in the theoretical fundamentals of the complementary disciplines of pragmatics and discourse analysis. They will also have learnt to grasp the fundamental theoretical difference between approaching these disciplines from the point of view of communicative intention or from that of social convention, and of the issues involved in giving theoretical priority in pragmatics and discourse analysis either to communicative intention or to social convention, or to some combination of the two.
- have learned above all to apply their knowledge of these fundamental theoretical issues to the practical business of analyzing naturally occurring discourse.

2) For students in MA English (Applied English Linguistics) or MPhil English (Applied English Linguistics)
courses.course_syllabus:
The first week will introduce students to the course and look at the question: What is/are discourse/discourses

In week 2, the history of the field of discourse studies will be explored with the implications of key texts and theorists discussed.

In week 3, Speech Act Theory and Gricean Maxims will be introduced with reference to students’ own linguistic experience. The concept of face will be discussed alongside Politeness Theory.

In Week 4 the importance of the ‘Other’ will be introduced with reference to intercultural communication.

Week 5 will introduce three discourse analytical approaches: Conversation Analysis, Ethnography, and Critical Discourse Analysis.

Week 6 will focus on Critical Discourse Studies and will introduce the importance of the question ‘cui bono?’, ‘who benefits?’

Week 7 returns to the concept of the ‘Other’ and how we create and maintain our identities through discourse

In week 8, we look at gender. How it is represented in discourse and what the challenges to such representation have been.

In week 9, students look at the critique of discourse analysis from a queer perspective. This introduces the notion of normativity and demonstrates the ways in which discourses themselves can be liberating and damaging.

Week 10 addresses the fact that discourse is not solely linguistic: it is multimodal. The social semiotic approach looks beyond the linguistic sign.

In week 11 we will look at advertising discourse and use the insights gained in earlier weeks to analyse various aspects of it.

In week 12, legitimation is identified as an all-encompassing concept that brings together all the aspects of the course.

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Second Language Writing
courses.description: This course focuses on current theories of writing and teaching writing and what they mean for EFL/ESL teachers. It introduces different methodologies, practices, and techniques commonly used in teaching L2 composition. It has a special focus on process and genre of writing as well as teacher and peer feedback in learning to write. It discusses the role of technology in promoting new models of writing classrooms. The course also has a practical aim of training how to design effective writing syllabuses, lessons, materials, and tasks to promote more effective writing. It emphasizes how to critically assess the effectiveness and appropriateness of sample syllabus.

courses.learning_outcomes: After completing this course, students will gain a thorough knowledge of the principles and methods relating to the teaching of writing to students who are second/foreign language speakers of English. In addition, they will be capable of critically evaluating writing courses and textbooks and designing writing lessons. Further, students will develop a sound understanding of research into second language writing, with emphasis on research conducted in Hong Kong.

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Computer Applications in Second Language Teaching
courses.description: This course enables students to understand the relationship between second language acquisition theories and computer applications to language learning (CALL) and gain familiarity with computer software and Internet resources available for English/second language teaching. Students learns to use computers and the Internet as teaching aids, design learning activities using a range of CALL software, and evaluate software and Internet resources for teaching purposes.

courses.learning_outcomes:

• Understand the major designs and trends of using the computer for second language teaching and learning
• Recognize the major issues related to successfully and effectively designing and using the computer for second language teaching and learning
• View and use computer as a tool to realize various learning objectives which are based on second language acquisition theories
• Implement and evaluation the CALL designs in your own courses
• Understand the roles computers can play in analyzing language
• Designing and conducting simple research using one common method of computer-assisted language studies: corpus linguistics (CL)
• Bring along better second language learning through this possibility of improved understanding of the language

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Cognitive Linguistics and Its Applications in Language Teaching
courses.description: This course provides an overview of the discipline of cognitive linguistics and its application in second language teaching. Cognitive linguists understand the language that we encounter every day as input from which we draw inferences about form-meaning relationships, typical patterns, and schemata. The course addresses core concepts in this area of study including: prototype, perspective, categorization, image schema, figure and ground, metaphor, metonymy, entrenchment, embodied cognition, gesture, construction grammar, attention and salience, and contingency learning. The course discusses how cognitive linguists design pedagogical methods and stimulate learners to explore the deeper meanings of grammatical forms.

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Research Project in Applied English Linguistics
courses.description:
This project-monitoring course aims to develop students’ basic academic skills through an independent, individual research project in a chosen area of applied English linguistics, guided by a supervisor. Students will be assessed through an oral presentation and a final written report of no more than 15,000 words.

Students who wish to enrol in the course should submit a 500-word proposal by the end of term 1 to seek prior approval from the MA in Applied English Linguistics programme team. The proposal should outline the research background, review key literature in the chosen topic, and describe the methodology adopted. Students should also have achieved a cumulative GPA of 3.3 or above in order to enrol in this course.

Prerequisite: ENGE5540 Research Methods in Applied Linguistics, which must be taken within the same academic year as this course.

(Note: This course may not be offered every year. In addition, the course will not be available for enrolment if ENGE5540 is not on offer in a particular year.)
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Pre-requisite = ENGE5540 and
For students in MA in English (Applied English Linguistics)
courses.course_syllabus: This is a project-monitoring course with individual supervision only. Each student who has successfully enrolled in this course will be assigned a supervisor. Rather than following a list of course topics, the supervisor will meet with the student regularly to provide support and guidance relevant to the student’s area of research. More specifically, the supervisor will guide the student to communicate research findings effectively in the forms of an oral presentation and a written report of approximately 15,000 words in length.
courses.feedback_evaluation: The supervisor will closely monitor the progress of the student throughout the semester. The student is encouraged to maintain regular contact with the supervisor and provide feedback on the format of supervisory meetings and level of guidance received, in response to which the supervisor will provide reflection on the students’ comments.
courses.required_readings: This is a project-monitoring course and the readings will be dependent on the student’s chosen topic of investigation. Students are however strongly recommended to equip themselves with general skills in academic writing and research methods in applied linguistics (see section on Recommended readings below).

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Digital Literacies: Theory, Research, and Practice
courses.description: Recognizing digital literacies as a social practice, this course highlights the differentiated, situated, and enculturated ways in which technology is used for diverse relational, informational, expressive, and recreational purposes. Beyond being a set of skills that support the needs of the knowledge economy, digital literacies are understood as practices that address new modes of productivity, representation, and sociality. Through the interplay of human and non-human interactants, technology has reshaped identities, communities, and relations of power, enabling social mobility, while also constructing new forms of inequality. By discussing current theory and research around digital literacies, this course illuminates how technology continues to transform the social landscape and examines the implications of these changes on language and literacy learning and the conceptualisation of 21st century competences.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA English (Applied English Linguistics) or MPhil English (Applied English Linguistics)
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students will have been able to:

• explore how technology has impacted the social landscape and the global flow of people, knowledge, and capital

• identify digital literacies that serve various relational, informational, expressive, and recreational purposes

• recognize how digital literacies range from the functional to the critical

• understand issues of digital equity and social fragmentation online

• examine how digital literacies are conceptualised and addressed in educational curricula
courses.course_syllabus:
• digital media and the transformation of the social landscape

• polyfocality and the attention economy

• digital security, privacy, and surveillance

• digital equity and social fragmentation

• online curation of identities

• information literacy

• functional vs. critical digital literacies

• online genres and sociotechnical structures

• digital literacy frameworks and educational curricula

courses.title: Language Policy and Planning (LPP)
courses.description: Language Policy and Planning (LPP) studies the linguistic, sociocultural, economic, educational, and socio-political dimensions of decisions about the use, role, and status of languages across spaces. As an interdisciplinary field, LPP investigates how and why institutions, communities, and individuals create, negotiate, and implement language policies. This course aims to engage students in understanding and analysing the theories, research practices, impacts, and implications of LPP across spaces such as school/university, family, workplace, and public places. The course engages students in critical analyses of how language policies shapes language learning, socialization, identities (e.g., race, ethnicity, and social class), ideologies and inequalities. The major topics to be covered in the course are: language ideology, language education policy (including English as a medium of instruction and multilingual education), family language policy (FLP), agency in language policy, and linguistic landscape. Students will read research-based texts and participate in discussions to examine language policies from diverse world contexts, including minority language contexts.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA English (Applied English Linguistics) or MPhil English (Applied English Linguistics)
courses.learning_outcomes:
By taking this course, the students are expected to:

* Examine different theories, methods, and research findings in language policy.
* Assess the factors shaping language education policies in multilingual contexts.
* Analyze the construction and reproduction of language ideologies in language policy in diverse world contexts.
* Develop the ability to analyze the role of different actors in creation, negotiation and implementation of language policies.
* Explore the interconnection between language policy, identity, learning, and social inequalities.
* Critically evaluate the impacts of language policy on the lives of people and communities.

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Social Dimensions of Second Language Acquisition
courses.description: Recognizing how second language acquisition (SLA) does not just involve cognitive, linguistic or psychological processes, this course examines how it is bound to and shaped by the social context in which these processes occur. By focusing on the social dimensions of L2 acquisition and learning, this course provides an overview of research strands such as Vygotskian sociocultural theory, language socialization, culture, identity, investment, and critical issues of race, ethnicity, gender, and social class. Because L2 acquisition and learning is mediated, embodied, situated and socially gated, multilingual learners continually negotiate their linguistic and semiotic resources as they navigate different contexts and perform diverse identities. By examining how the micro level of social activity is indexical of macrostructures of institutions, language policies, and cultural norms, language learning is ineluctably intertwined with issues of power, ideology, and inequality. This course weaves together these ideas into an integrative perspective of L2 acquisition that enables a critical understanding of real-world issues of language learning and teaching.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA English (Applied English Linguistics) or MPhil English (Applied English Linguistics)
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students will have been able to:
• Gain a fundamental understanding of how SLA has been theorized in different ways as a social process
• Examine how the negotiation of identities in different contexts shapes opportunities for language learning
• Develop a critical perspective of language acquisition, learning and teaching as processes circumscribed by power and ideologies
• Understand how the social dimensions of SLA can develop a fuller understanding of global, real-world multilingual educational contexts
• Reflect on how critical awareness of social dimensions can shape transformative language learning and teaching practices.
courses.course_syllabus:
Topics and fundamental concepts
• Vygotskian sociocultural theory
• Language socialization
• Culture, diversity and language learning
• Translanguaging and the linguistic and semiotic resources of learners
• Critical issues of power, ideology and inequality
• Identity and issues of race, ethnicity, gender and social class
• Investment in language and literacy practices
• Implications of social dimensions of SLA on language learning and teaching

Midway through the term, you will also be asked to provide feedback on the course.

courses.title: Second Language Reading Research and Teaching
courses.description: This course is designed to help students have a firm grasp of the fundamental theories of second language reading and thereby equip improved research and teaching skills. It begins with a discussion on the nature of reading and the differences between reading in first vs second languages. Then, various models of reading comprehension will be reviewed, including process models (bottom-up, top-down, and interactive) and component models (background knowledge, grammar, vocabulary, etc.). This course then reviews cognitive aspects of reading such as readers’ working memory, the relationship between reading rate and reading comprehension, and the impact of L1 orthographic system on L2 reading. In addition, this course delves into the pedagogical aspects of second language reading, such as the use of graded readers based on readability indices, the relationship between second language reading and second language acquisition, and lastly, how to better utilize tasks and technology in teaching second language reading.

courses.description: The course aims at providing the students with an orientation of critical and interpretive approaches required of graduate studies in literature in a cross-cultural context. Various literary and critical paradigms from Western and Chinese traditions will be reviewed with a discussion of the basic issues in interpretation theory and criticism. The course will also focus on the implications of recent orientations in social sciences and philosophy for literary studies. Students will be required to identify their own research interests and pursue text- based case studies on problems or topics in criticism and interpretive theory that are involved in the interdisciplinary studies of literature.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA English (Literary Studies) or MPhil English (Literary Studies)
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to:

• Understand key concepts of a range of critical approaches to the study of literature.
• Debate the pros and cons of such approaches and begin to develop personal preferences and affinities to a critical school or schools.
• Choose a suitable approach or experiment with different approaches in the reading of literary texts and be alert to the merits and demerits of their choice.
• Articulate their observations and thoughts in discussions, presentations and papers.
• Relate the study of literature and theory to broader issues in politics, knowledge production, and society.

courses.subject: ENGE
courses.title: Comparative Approaches in Literary Studies
courses.description: The course serves as an introduction to the advanced study of literature from comparative perspectives. With a view to enhancing their ability in identifying problems and topics for research, students will be familiarized, through team-work instruction, with the basic techniques and methods of bibliographical research and textual criticism. This will involve the use of specific primary texts. Emphasis will be put on giving the students an overview of historical as well as current research in the field. The concept of comparative literature will be investigated along with the various cultural as well as literary issues particularly involved in the studies of literature in the Chinese-Western context. Traditional areas of research, such as influence and reception, themes and motifs, genres and forms, and interrelations of literature and art, will be reviewed in the light of recent literary and cultural theories. In this course students will have to read major literary and critical texts with regard to the various perspectives on comparative literature.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil English (Literary Studies) or MA English (Literary Studies)
courses.learning_outcomes: This course will acquaint graduate students with a number of basic concepts of theoretical positions in literary criticism, enable them to approach literature from a variety of perspectives, equip them with practical knowledge of how literary scholars develop their interpretations, and lead them to greater understanding of the primary features, strategies and implications of the main currents in literary theory and criticism such as new criticism, reader-response criticism, structuralism, deconstruction, psychoanalytic criticism, feminism, Marxism, new historicism, and cultural studies.

courses.title: Special Topic(s) in Genre Studies
courses.description: Specific area(s) of investigation will be defined every year to cover one or more of the following aspects in the critical and comparative studies of literary genre: poetics, prosaics; dramatic theories; narrative theories; questions of form and structure; issues in theme and style; concepts of character and hero; problems of generic convention and institution; as well as other topics related to the study of particular genres or subgenres of poetry, drama and fiction. Emphasis will be put on the dialectic between theory and practice. Textual analysis will be treated in relation to the critical investigation of possible cultural and historical contexts. Subject to the approval of the Division Head, students are allowed to take the above course more than once and gain the units each time they pass the course. However, students cannot take courses with the same course code more than once in a single term.

courses.description: Specific area(s) of investigation will be defined every year to cover one or more of the following aspects in the critical and comparative studies of literary history: influence and reception; period and movement; literary ideas and intellectual history; historicism; neohistoricism; classicism; neo-classicism; romanticism; symbolism; realism; modernism; postmodernism; functions and theories of literary history; perspectives of historical criticism; concepts of literary tradition; concepts of literary system; literary history and literary reception; feminist perspectives; materialist perspectives; problems of textuality and intertextuality. The chosen area(s) of investigation will use texts from all three major genres of poetry, drama, and fiction. Subject to the approval of the Division Head, students are allowed to take the above course more than once and gain the units each time they pass the course. Subject specific skills

courses.description: In this course, the supervisor will meet with the student on a regular basis to give advice on all matters related to the preparation of a thesis proposal.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil English (Applied English Linguistics) or MPhil English (Literary Studies)
courses.learning_outcomes: 1. Demonstrated progress in research plan through regular contact with the supervisor. 2. Production of a research paper that leads to the writing of the dissertation.
courses.course_syllabus: This is a project-monitoring course with individual supervision only. Each student who has successfully enrolled in this course will be assigned a supervisor. Rather than following a list of course topics, the supervisor will meet with the student regularly to provide support and guidance relevant to the student’s area of research. More specifically, the supervisor will guide the student to communicate research findings effectively in the forms of an oral presentation.
courses.feedback_evaluation: The supervisor will closely monitor the progress of the student throughout the semester. The student is encouraged to maintain regular contact with the supervisor and provide feedback on the format of supervisory meetings and level of guidance received, in response to which the supervisor will provide reflection on the students’ comments.
courses.required_readings: This is a project-monitoring course and the readings will be dependent on the student’s chosen topic of investigation. Students are however strongly recommended to equip themselves with general skills in academic writing and research methods.
